Hello All,

I also work for Parasoft in the sales organization, but I think=
 I may 
be able to shed some light upon the subject.  Let me see if I can 
=
clarify a bit about the @pre tag.  When Jtest automatically generates 
test=
 cases for a method, it will read this tag and not generate any 
input whic=
h specifically violates the defined pre-condition.  If an 
@post tag is pre=
sent, Jtest will try to generate inputs which would 
adhere to the @pre con=
dition, but intentionally try to break the 
@post condition.  If the @post =
condition were able to be violated, 
this would indicate a serious flaw in =
the code.

Also, Jtest can report a @pre violation if the method with the @=
pre 
tag is called by another method and that @pre condition is violated.
F=
or example, let's say you have method A which calls method B.  
Method B ha=
s some @pre defined and Jtest generates a test for method 
A which calls me=
thod B in such a manner which violates method B's 
@pre condition.  Here, J=
test would report a @pre violation.

These particular features are related =
to DBC.  The above is just a 
small subset of what ParaSoft's tools can do =
in relation to DBC.  If 
you want more info on DBC, you can go to 
http://w=
ww.parasoft.com/jsp/products/article.jsp?
articleId=3D579&product=3DJcontra=
ct

Regards,
David McCaw



--- In junit@y..., Ilja Preu=DF <ilja.preuss@w.=
..> wrote:
> What exactly does the @pre tag do? Does it test that the metho=
d 
fails if called with an invalid value?
> 
> > --- In junit@y..., "rxqch"=
 <rxqch@y...> wrote:
> > > Hi, I work with parasoft tech support and the an=
swer to the
> > question 
> > > below is yes.  One can use an @pre tag in j=
avadoc to find such 
> > > problems.
> > > 
> > > Carson
> > > 
> > > --- I=
n junit@y..., Ilja Preu=DF <ilja.preuss@w...> wrote:
> > > > > The problem =
is that I don't know if there was a problem with
> > > > > the input, the p=
rocessing or something random. If your code
> > > > > returns an IllegalArg=
umentException, then I have a much
> > > > > better idea of the issues.
> >=
 > > 
> > > > If you are on the same team, you could ask him. Possibly you
=
> > could 
> > > even
> > > > find out by simply looking at the code and/or=
 the JUnit tests.
> > > > 
> > > > One point I find more critical is that i=
nvalid input should be
> > > > fail-fast. If a method fails because you pro=
vided invalid 
input
> > to a
> > > > prior method call, such problems are =
really hard to find. Can
> > JTest 
> > > help
> > > > with such issues?
> =
> > > 
> > > > Regards, Ilja
